inputs: FEN: rn1q1rk1/pb1pppbp/1p3np1/2p5/2P5/1PN2NP1/PB1PPPBP/R2Q1RK1 b - - 4 8. Best move: d7d5. Evaluation: 14. Explain why d7d5 is the best move.
label: If White strikes first with the advance of his d-pawn, then Black is able to equalize with 8.d4 cxd4 9.Qxd4 Nc6 10.Qd2 d5 11.cxd5 Qxd5, for example 12.Nd4 Ne4! 13.Nxc6 Qxc6 14.Bxg7 Kxg7 15.Qe3 Qc5 16.Qxc5 Nxc5 17.Bxb7 Nxb7 18.Nc3 Rac8 19.Rac1 Rfd8, is completely equal, Barcza-Steiner, Budapest 1948. If we compare this situation to the one that occurs in the line after 8.Nc3 d5, we note that here Black has completed his development and is able to challenge White on the c- and d-files with his rooks.

inputs: FEN: rn1q1rk1/pb2ppbp/1p3np1/2pp4/2P5/1PN2NP1/PB1PPPBP/R2Q1RK1 w - - 0 9. Best move: c3d5. Evaluation: 25. Explain why c3d5 is the best move.
label: Black breaks the symmetry of moves and provokes the following flurry of exchanges. In my opinion this move is a little dubious and Black can instead equalize in the variation with 8...Na6!

inputs: FEN: rn1q1rk1/pb2ppbp/1p3np1/2pN4/2P5/1P3NP1/PB1PPPBP/R2Q1RK1 b - - 0 9. Best move: f6d5. Evaluation: 7. Explain why f6d5 is the best move.
label: The only correct way to proceed. If 9.cxd5?! Nxd5 10.Na4 Bxb2 11.Nxb2 Nc6, Black has at least equalized as the White knight on b2 is misplaced.

inputs: FEN: rn3r2/pb2ppkp/1p4p1/2pq4/8/1P3NP1/P2PPPBP/R2Q1RK1 w - - 0 12. Best move: d2d4. Evaluation: 14. Explain why d2d4 is the best move.
label: The exchanging sequence is forcing, as 11...Bxd5 12.d4, is good for White. Note that White wins immediately after 12...cxd4? 13.Qxd4+ Kg8 14.Rfd1, pinning and winning Black's bishop.

inputs: FEN: rn3r2/pb2ppkp/1p4p1/3q4/3p4/1P3NP1/P3PPBP/R2Q1RK1 w - - 0 13. Best move: f3e1. Evaluation: 10. Explain why f3e1 is the best move.
label: Black's last opportunity to avoid the endgame that occurs in the game is 12...Na6, when it is probably easier for Black to demonstrate equality.

inputs: FEN: rn3r2/pb2ppkp/1p4p1/3q4/3Q4/1P3NP1/P3PPBP/R4RK1 b - - 0 13. Best move: d5d4. Evaluation: 16. Explain why d5d4 is the best move.
label: Less effective is 13.Nh4 Qd7 14.Bxb7 Qxb7 15.Qxd4+ Kg8 16.Rfd1 Nc6 17.Qd7 (17.Qe4 Rfd8 18.Nf3 0.5-0.5 Sanguinetti-Panno, Buenos Aires 1977) 17...Qxd7 18.Rxd7 Rfd8 0.5-0.5 Tal-Salov, Brussels 1988. In both cases Black equalized.

inputs: FEN: rn3r2/p3ppkp/1p4p1/8/3N4/1P4P1/P3PPKP/R4R2 b - - 0 15. Best move: a7a5. Evaluation: 12. Explain why a7a5 is the best move.
FEN: rn3r2/4ppkp/pp4p1/8/3N4/1P4P1/P3PPKP/R4R2 w - - 0 16. Best move: a1c1. Evaluation: 26. Explain why a1c1 is the best move.
label:
Black prevents the possibility of Nc3-b5 and prepares to develop his rook with Ra8-a7 to facilitate doubling of the rooks on the c- or d-file (if allowed). Alternatives include:
15...Nd7, and now:
A) 16.Rfd1 Nf6 17.Nb5! Rfc8 18.Rac1 Rxc1 (if 18...a6? 19.Nc7 Rab8 20.Nxa6 Rxc1 21.Rxc1 Ra8 22.Nb4, and White has won a pawn) 19.Rxc1 a6 20.Nd4 Rd8 21.e3 Nd5 22.Rc6 Rd6 23.Rxd6! exd6 24.Kf1, and White enjoys an advantage in the knight endgame thanks to his better pawn structure, Andersson-Marovic, Banja Luka 1976.
B) 16.Rac1 Rfc8 17.Rfd1, and now:
B1) 17...Nc5 18.b4! Ne4 (18...Na4 19.Nb5! Rxc1 20.Rxc1 a5 21.a3! with a clear advantage for White Smyslov-Benko, Monte Carlo 1968, while worse is 18...Nd7? 19.Ne6+ fxe6 20.Rxc8 Rxc8 21.Rxd7, with a winning endgame for White) 19.Nb5! Rxc1 20.Rxc1 a5 21.Rc4, with an edge for White, Lisitsyn-Levenfish, USSR Ch. 1948.
B2) 17...Kf6 18.Nb5 Rxc1 19.Rxc1 Nc5 20.b4, with an edge for White, Ribli-Sapi, Budapest 1976. These examples show how White's Nd4-b5 idea can make life awkward for Black.
An interesting try is 15...Na6!? 16.Rfd1 Rfc8 17.Rac1, and now:
A) 17...Kf6 18.Nb5 Rxc1 (18...Nc5? - losing a pawn - 19.b4 Ne6 20.Rxc8 Rxc8 21.Nxa7, with a big advantage for White, Smyslov-Castro Rojas, Biel 1976) 19.Rxc1 Nc5 20.b4 Ne6 21.Rc6, reaches a position that occurred in the game Portisch-Pachman, Sarajevo 1963, when White stood better.
B) 17...Nb4 18.Rxc8 (Possible is 18.a3, when White may have a slight pull) 18...Rxc8 19.Rd2 a6 0.5-0.5 Benko-Weinstein, Lone Pine 1975.
Also possible is 15...Rc8, when 16.Rac1 Nd7 17.Rfd1 transposes to variations examined after 15...Nd7.

inputs: FEN: rn3r2/4ppkp/pp4p1/8/3N4/1P4P1/P3PPKP/2R2R2 b - - 1 16. Best move: a8a7. Evaluation: 29. Explain why a8a7 is the best move.
label: 16.Rfc1 Ra7 17.Rc2 (17.e3 Rd7 18.Rc2 e5?! 19.Nf3 f6 20.g4! with advantage to White, Szabo-Bisguier, Gothenburg 1955) 17...Rd8 18.e3 Kf8 (18...e5 19.Nf3 f6 20.Rac1, is good for White) 19.Rac1 Ke8 20.g4! (this idea is thematic - gaining space on the kingside while Black is busy preventing White from penetrating on the queenside) 20...h6 21.h4 Rad7 22.f4 a5 23.Kf3 Rd6 24.h5! with a clear plus for White, Andersson-Hort, Niksic 1978.

inputs: FEN: 1n1r4/r3ppkp/pp4p1/8/3N4/1P2P1P1/P1R2PKP/5R2 b - - 0 18. Best move: a7d7. Evaluation: 30. Explain why a7d7 is the best move.
label: White anchors his centralized knight.

inputs: FEN: 1n1r4/r4pkp/pp4p1/4p3/3N4/1P2P1P1/P1R2PKP/5R2 w - - 0 19. Best move: d4f3. Evaluation: 29. Explain why d4f3 is the best move.
label:
A mistake, as White will be able to capitalize on the resultant weakening of the Black pawn structure.
Better is 18...Kf8 19.Rfc1, transposing to the Andersson-Hort game in the previous note, although as we saw, White also enjoys more pleasant prospects in that instance.

inputs: FEN: 1n1r4/r5kp/pp3pp1/4p3/8/1P2PNP1/P1R2PKP/5R2 w - - 0 20. Best move: g3g4. Evaluation: 81. Explain why g3g4 is the best move.
label: Passively defending the e-pawn with 19...Re7 can be met with 20.Rfc1 Kf8 21.Rc8, and White stands better.

inputs: FEN: 1n1r4/r5kp/pp3pp1/4p3/6P1/1P2PN2/P1R2PKP/5R2 b - - 0 20. Best move: a6a5. Evaluation: 59. Explain why a6a5 is the best move.
label: White gains space on the kingside and has a perceptible advantage.

inputs: FEN: 8/r2n2kp/ppR2pp1/4p3/6P1/1P2PN2/P4PKP/8 b - - 0 23. Best move: b6b5. Evaluation: 126. Explain why b6b5 is the best move.
label: An exchange of rooks has exposed Black's tender spots along his third rank (b6, d6).

inputs: FEN: 8/r2n1k1p/ppR2pp1/4p3/6P1/1P2P3/P2N1PKP/8 b - - 2 24. Best move: f7e7. Evaluation: 174. Explain why f7e7 is the best move.
label: Andersson redirects his knight to the more lucrative outpost on e4.

inputs: FEN: 8/r2nk2p/ppR2pp1/4p3/6P1/1P2P3/P2N1PKP/8 w - - 3 25. Best move: d2e4. Evaluation: 166. Explain why d2e4 is the best move.
label: Keeping the knight out of e4 with 24...f5? allows White to post the knight efficiently elsewhere with 25.gxf5 gxf5 26.Nc4, and Black is losing a pawn, as 26...b5 allows 27.Nd6+ etc.

inputs: FEN: 8/1r1nk2p/ppR2pp1/4p3/1P2N1P1/4P3/P4PKP/8 b - - 0 26. Best move: b7a7. Evaluation: 219. Explain why b7a7 is the best move.
label: Effectively binding Black's position.

inputs: FEN: 1r6/3nk2p/ppR2pp1/4p3/1P4P1/2N1P3/P4PKP/8 b - - 2 27. Best move: f6f5. Evaluation: 228. Explain why f6f5 is the best move.
label: Andersson now directs his knight to the more powerful post on d5.

inputs: FEN: 1r6/3nk2p/ppR3p1/4pp2/1P4P1/2N1P3/P4PKP/8 w - - 0 28. Best move: c3d5. Evaluation: 207. Explain why c3d5 is the best move.
label: If 27...Rb7 28.Nd5+ Kf7 then 29.e4! leaves Black without any useful move, for example 29...a5 (29...Rb8 30.Rc7, and White wins a pawn after 30...Ke6 31.Ra7 a5 32.bxa5 bxa5 33.Ra6+ Kf7 34.Rxa5, etc., while 29...Kg7 is met by 30.Re6! g5 31.Re7+ Kg6 32.Ne3, and the Black king is practically in a mating net) 30.b5, maintains the bind - Black is running out of moves.

inputs: FEN: 1r6/3n1k2/ppR3p1/3Npp1p/1P4P1/4P1K1/P4P1P/8 w - - 0 30. Best move: g4g5. Evaluation: 246. Explain why g4g5 is the best move.
label: White's king penetrates easily after this move by Black. But even after 29...fxg4 30.Kxg4, there is a grim defensive task for Black.

inputs: FEN: 8/1r1n1k2/pp1R4/3Npp1p/1P5K/4P3/P4P1P/8 b - - 3 32. Best move: a6a5. Evaluation: 281. Explain why a6a5 is the best move.
label: Andersson introduces his king as the last attacking unit in his endgame attack. Black's kingside pawns have become easy targets.

inputs: FEN: 8/1r1n2k1/pp1R4/3Npp1K/1P6/4P3/P4P1P/8 b - - 0 33. Best move: a6a5. Evaluation: 348. Explain why a6a5 is the best move.
label:
The continuation might be 33...a5 34.b5 Kf7 (34...Kh7? loses to 35.Rxd7+ Rxd7 36.Nf6+) 35.Kg5, and White wins another pawn.
What we learn from a study of a game such as this is that no matter how quiet or simplified a position may appear on the surface, active and accurate defense is paramount as any mistake can lead to a technically lost endgame (with almost certain fatal consequences).

inputs: FEN: rnbqkb1r/p1pp1ppp/1p2pn2/8/2PP4/P4N2/1P2PPPP/RNBQKB1R b KQkq - 0 4. Best move: c8b7. Evaluation: 19. Explain why c8b7 is the best move.
label: Kasparov had a fondness for this system of Petrosian's in the 1980s.

inputs: FEN: rn1qkb1r/pbpp1ppp/1p2p3/8/2PPn3/P1N2N2/1P2PPPP/R1BQKB1R w KQkq - 3 6. Best move: c3e4. Evaluation: 38. Explain why c3e4 is the best move.
label: This method of seeking early exchanges is distinctly dubious.

inputs: FEN: rn1qkb1r/p1pp1ppp/1p2p3/8/2PPb3/P7/1P1NPPPP/R1BQKB1R b KQkq - 1 7. Best move: e4b7. Evaluation: 46. Explain why e4b7 is the best move.
label: From a strategical standpoint, this move refutes Black's opening. Now Black can retreat with 7...Bb7 but after 8.e4, White has a distinct positional advantage.

inputs: FEN: rn1qkb1r/p1pp1ppp/1p2p1b1/8/2PP4/P5P1/1P1NPP1P/R1BQKB1R b KQkq - 0 8. Best move: f8e7. Evaluation: 74. Explain why f8e7 is the best move.
label: Now that the Black bishop has departed from the h1-a8 diagonal, Kasparov takes it for himself.

inputs: FEN: r2qkb1r/p1pp1ppp/1pn1p1b1/8/2PP4/P5P1/1P1NPP1P/R1BQKB1R w KQkq - 1 9. Best move: e2e3. Evaluation: 73. Explain why e2e3 is the best move.
label: It would seem more appropriate to play 8...c6 9.Bg2 d5, but after 10.0-0, White has the freer and easier game to play.

inputs: FEN: r2qkb1r/2pp1ppp/ppn1p1b1/8/2PP4/P3P1P1/1P1N1P1P/R1BQKB1R w KQkq - 0 10. Best move: h2h4. Evaluation: 104. Explain why h2h4 is the best move.
label: Andersson seeks counterplay with b6-b5, but his lag in development is a cause for concern.

inputs: FEN: r2qkb1r/2pp1ppp/p1n1p1b1/1p6/1PPP4/P3P1P1/3N1P1P/R1BQKB1R w KQkq - 0 11. Best move: c4b5. Evaluation: 133. Explain why c4b5 is the best move.
label: After 10...d5 11.Bb2 Be7 12.Rc1 Qd7 13.Bg2 0-0 14.cxd5 exd5 15.Qb3, White has a clear advantage.

inputs: FEN: r2qkb1r/n1pp1ppp/4p1b1/1p6/1P1P4/P3P1P1/1B1N1P1P/R2QKB1R w KQkq - 2 13. Best move: h2h4. Evaluation: 145. Explain why h2h4 is the best move.
label: Ulf Andersson has a reputation for being a very patient and solid defender, and thus a very difficult man to beat. This retreat of the knight has a view to the maneuver Na7-c8, followed by d7-d5 and Nc8-d6-c4. But White has some moves first!

inputs: FEN: r2qkb1r/n1pp1ppp/4p1b1/1p6/1P1P3P/P3P1P1/1B1N1P2/R2QKB1R b KQkq - 0 13. Best move: h7h5. Evaluation: 151. Explain why h7h5 is the best move.
label: Exploiting the misplaced "Queen's Indian bishop. "

inputs: FEN: r2qkb1r/n1pp1pp1/4p1bp/1p6/1P1P3P/P3P1P1/1B1N1P2/R2QKB1R w KQkq - 0 14. Best move: h4h5. Evaluation: 191. Explain why h4h5 is the best move.
label: Better was 13...h5.

inputs: FEN: r2qkb1r/n1pp1pp1/4p1bp/1p1P4/1P5P/P3P1P1/1B1N1P2/R2QKB1R b KQkq - 0 14. Best move: e6d5. Evaluation: 215. Explain why e6d5 is the best move.
label: A strong positional pawn sacrifice that opens the long diagonal for White's dark-squared bishop.

inputs: FEN: r2qkb1r/n2p1pp1/2p3bp/1p1p4/1P5P/P3P1P1/1B1N1PB1/R2Q1RK1 b kq - 1 16. Best move: f7f5. Evaluation: 219. Explain why f7f5 is the best move.
label: White's compensation for his pawn is enormous - a massive lead in development, two raking bishops, and a weakness on g7 that prevents Black catching up in development in a normal manner.

inputs: FEN: r2qkb1r/n2p2p1/2p2pbp/1p1p4/1P5P/P3P1P1/1B1N1PB1/R2QR1K1 b kq - 1 17. Best move: g6f7. Evaluation: 219. Explain why g6f7 is the best move.
label: The target is the Black king, with the e3-e4 break scheduled.

inputs: FEN: r2q3r/n2pbkp1/2p2pbp/1p1p3P/1P4Q1/P3P1P1/1B1N1PB1/R3R1K1 b - - 0 19. Best move: g6h7. Evaluation: 297. Explain why g6h7 is the best move.
label: Now after the inevitable exchange of light-squared bishops, White will have the g6-square at his disposal as an invasion point for his queen.

inputs: FEN: r2q3r/n2pbkp1/2p2p1p/1p5P/1P2N1Q1/P5P1/1B3P2/R3R1K1 b - - 0 22. Best move: a7c8. Evaluation: 333. Explain why a7c8 is the best move.
label: Now there are all manner of tactics brewing against the f6 and g7 points in the Black position.

inputs: FEN: r1nq3r/3pbkp1/2p2p1p/1p5P/1P2N1Q1/P5P1/1B3P2/R3R1K1 w - - 1 23. Best move: a1d1. Evaluation: 319. Explain why a1d1 is the best move.
FEN: 2nq3r/r2pbkp1/2p2p1p/1p5P/1P2N1Q1/P5P1/1B3P2/3RR1K1 w - - 3 24. Best move: b2d4. Evaluation: 359. Explain why b2d4 is the best move.
label: Also hopeless is 23...d5 24.Nxf6! gxf6 (24...Bxf6 25.Qg6+ Kf8 26.Bxf6 gxf6 27.Re6! wins for White.) 25.Qg6+ Kf8 26.Bc1 Qe8 (26...Ra7 represents a transposition to the game.) 27.Bxh6+ Rxh6 28.Qxh6+ Kg8 29.Rd4, and the Black king is doomed.

inputs: FEN: 2nq3r/r2pbk2/2p2p1p/1p5P/1P4Q1/P5P1/1B3P2/3RR1K1 w - - 0 25. Best move: g4g6. Evaluation: 253. Explain why g4g6 is the best move.
label: White also wins after 24...Bxf6 25.Qg6+ Kf8 26.Bxf6 gxf6 27.Re6.

inputs: FEN: 2nq1k1r/r3b3/2p2pQp/1p1p3P/1P6/P5P1/5P2/2BRR1K1 w - - 0 27. Best move: d1d4. Evaluation: 446. Explain why d1d4 is the best move.
label: Nor can Black defend after 26...Qe8 27.Bxh6+ Rxh6 28.Qxh6+ Kg8 29.Rd4 f5 30.Qg5+! Kh8 31.Qxf5.

inputs: FEN: 3q1k1r/r3bn2/2p2pQB/1p1p3P/1P4R1/P5P1/5P2/4R1K1 b - - 0 29. Best move: f7h6. Evaluation: 621. Explain why f7h6 is the best move.
label: A final knock-out punch. The bishop cannot be captured because of immediate mate.

inputs: FEN: 3qk2r/r3bnB1/2p2pQ1/1p1p3P/1P4R1/P5P1/5P2/4R1K1 b - - 2 30. Best move: e8d7. Evaluation: 601. Explain why e8d7 is the best move.
label:
Black Resigned 
After the forced 30...Rg8, then simply 31.h6 decides the issue. A powerful tour de force by Kasparov.
